stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the stream rebuilding an overworld section that contains a forest, bridges and a plane-minigame entrance.  He fixes AI lag, remodels bridges, prototypes a mixed 2D/3D tree system, reviews Course 4 beta-test feedback, and stress-tests the scene on real N64 hardware while chatting with contributors.

development_findings.summary: The original timed plane mission in the overworld has been scrapped; the new goal is to reach the end while managing damage, re-using the ‘retro plane’ physics from the Super Mario Land section.
development_findings.quote: We're gonna make it so that you take damage from the stuff, so the goal will be to get to the end without taking as much damage instead of the time limit.

development_findings.summary: Course 4 (the zoo) finished its first full beta; general layout was approved, but bugs and the plane mission were poorly received and will be reworked.
development_findings.quote: Beta test 1 of course 4 happened this weekend … the level overall seems decent except the bugs sucked and the plane mission sucked.

development_findings.summary: Kaze rebuilt a previously ‘steppy’ bridge with Blender Bézier curves to create a smoother traversal path and plans to apply matching 3-D railings.
development_findings.quote: So you see how steppy this bridge is? I don't like it. This new bridge will be so much smoother.

development_findings.summary: A new overworld ‘trophy building’ will track optional Easter-egg challenges; collected trophies appear and two adjacent blank ones give hints for future tasks, à-la Smash Bros. Brawl milestones.
development_findings.quote: You collect one trophy and you get two hints for the next two trophies.

development_findings.summary: Forest visuals: decided on a layered solution—2-D tree walls behind rows of low-poly 3-D trees with vertex coloring; experimenting with Zeina’s 640×640 canopy textures to avoid overdraw and color mismatch.
development_findings.quote: I think a background of 2D walls of trees with 3D trees in front of it could work.

development_findings.summary: Real-hardware test on an N64 shows the new forest area holds 32-50 FPS even with a water-render bug, easing worries about ‘triple overdraw’ performance.
development_findings.quote: We have 32 FPS here, with the messed-up water bug. I think we're fine.

development_findings.summary: The hack now contains roughly 480 dialogue boxes—about triple vanilla Mario 64—implying a significantly larger game world.
development_findings.quote: We have 480 dialogs in this game right now, which is around three times what vanilla Mario 64 had.

development_findings.summary: EverDrive X7 currently fails to boot the hack; Kaze suspects the fault lies in his own code and has flagged it for a future fix.
development_findings.quote: The X7 had an issue where it couldn't run my mod, but that might as well also be an issue in my mod and not of the X7.

development_findings.summary: Kaze wrote a new in-engine neuro-evolution tool that can train an AI inside Mario 64, building on a previous prototype that ‘sucked’.
development_findings.quote: Now I have a thing that can train an AI inside Mario 64 to play Mario 64, and I think it can be really cool.

development_findings.summary: A custom ‘sound composer’ lets Badub create environmental SFX; rotor sounds were added to make the overworld feel more alive.
development_findings.quote: With the sound composer I made, Badub is able to make sound effects … it makes the environment instantly feel like two times as alive.

context_findings.summary: Sponsor money dictates video cadence; as long as Squarespace pays, Kaze will post every two weeks.
context_findings.quote: You better pray that Squarespace keeps paying up because as long as Squarespace pays I'm probably gonna make a video every two weeks.

context_findings.summary: Kaze dismisses FPGA consoles for consumers, arguing emulators are better and that refusing to send him a review unit signals ‘shady’ hardware.
context_findings.quote: FPGAs are cool research projects, but as a consumer product I think they are 100 percent worthless. Just set up an emulator.

context_findings.summary: He views language wars as pointless, claiming only weak programmers fixate on which language is used.
context_findings.quote: The only people that care about which programming language you use are people that are not very good at programming.

context_findings.summary: He celebrated an upcoming 800 k-view YouTube video edited by Okayo, showing excitement over public reach.
context_findings.quote: Oh my god, it's doing so well … Okayo has wanted an 800 000 view video since the day we started working together and I think he's finally getting it.

context_findings.summary: Side hustle anecdote: flipped $80 of Yu-Gi-Oh cards for $230, reflecting a pragmatic view on finances.
context_findings.quote: Just like five or six more Yu-Gi-Oh flips and I'm a billionaire.

biobak.summary: Proposed the overworld ‘trophy building’ system and discussed UI details (hint distribution, readability).
biobak.quote: What if you go into the trophy room and … around the trophy you collected, there is a blacked-out trophy that gives you a hint?

biobak.summary: Gave design feedback on bridges, fences and overworld props; Kaze incorporated several suggestions.

badub.summary: Used Kaze’s new sound composer to add rotor ambience, enhancing environmental audio.
badub.quote: With the sound composer I made, Badub is able to make sound effects.

zeina.summary: Previously created high-resolution (640×640) foliage textures that Kaze is adapting for the new forest.
zeina.quote: This is a texture Zeina made, and I think she draws them in 640×640.

key_stories.title: Redesigning the Plane Minigame
key_stories.summary: Initial timed plane section felt weak and testers disliked it.  Kaze pivots to a damage-management challenge using existing retro plane physics.
key_stories.challenge: Timed objective was unfun and the mission ‘sucked’ in beta.
key_stories.process: Repurposed the proven Super Mario Land plane code, removed timer, added damaging obstacles.
key_stories.outcome: New version is considered ‘a lot more fun’; awaiting next test.
key_stories.key_quote: I think this is gonna be a lot more fun than what we had before—the plane mission sucked.

key_stories.title: Inventing the Trophy Room
key_stories.summary: During chat brainstorming, Biobak suggests a building that displays trophies for secret feats.  Kaze refines it into a two-hint milestone system reminiscent of Smash Bros.
key_stories.challenge: Overworld lacked engaging, optional content and presentational flair.
key_stories.process: Live discussion shaped rules: collected trophies visible; adjacent blanks give hints; not required for completion.
key_stories.outcome: Idea logged for implementation; not yet guaranteed but ‘random ideas like that—we just make them’.
key_stories.key_quote: Random ideas like that… we just make them.

key_stories.title: Forest Performance vs. Aesthetics
key_stories.summary: Creating a convincing jungle backdrop risked overdraw and frame drops.  Kaze experiments with 2-D walls plus low-poly 3-D trees, then validates on real hardware.
key_stories.challenge: Need dense foliage without killing N64 performance.
key_stories.process: Layered tree concept, custom textures, vertex coloring; ran scene on console to profile FPS.
key_stories.outcome: Achieved 32-50 FPS; visual tweaks ongoing (leaf textures, color matching).
key_stories.key_quote: Honestly, on N64 this looks even more like a real forest… I think we're fine.
